http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1917, the Japanese Government extended a second link from Nagasaki to Taiwan.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

“The Great Northern Telegraph Company Centenary Book,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Books/GNT/.
“Umegasaki Stories,” Nagasaki: People, Places and Scenes of the Nagasaki Foreign Settlement 1859-1941, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.nfs.nias.ac.jp/page007.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You make your way through sludge and silt to come ashore – quite a different experience from the clear seawater of the southern Japanese islands. A Spanish and then Dutch colony in the seventeenth century, Tanshui (also known as Dansheui) grew to become the largest port in Taiwan by the late 1800s. Coal and tea were exported in vast quantities from the natural harbor where the Tanshui (or Tamsui) River meets the Strait of Taiwan. In 1887, an underwater telegraph cable joined the bustling city to Fuzhou on the Chinese mainland, and a year later the Taipei Telegraph Academy opened nearby. But in the early twentieth century, the buildup of silt at the river mouth caused much of the shipping traffic to move east to Keelung. While its port status dwindled, Tanshui retained its position as an international cable hub. Several fiber-optic systems arrived in the early 2000s, linking the town to points throughout East Asia and the Pacific. Twin landing stations, owned by competing telecom carriers, are situated along a quiet beach west of the city, famous for vivid sunsets and a popular leisure destination for residents of Taipei.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific: Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Manchester. Each has an image of the station, and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

You are carried to shore at Baler with nine-foot waves surging overhead, curling in on themselves and frothing as they meet the warm, sandy beach. A smattering of palm trees line the coast, and before you, the earth rises up in rolling green mountains filled with waterfalls, caves, and springs. A cable landing point since 1964, Baler has become famous more for its surf than its land. Especially from October to March, when the waves are greatest, the sea fills with surfers who flock to Baler’s beaches. The waves loom large in people’s minds here: locals claim that sometimes the surf is so huge that they can hear it from the provincial capitol building, 1.5 km away from the coast. Like the cable, surfing came to this town because of global media flows. The film Apocalypse Now was shot here in the 1970s, and included a famous scene of American soldiers surfing. After filming, the crew left behind their boards and a new sport.

Completed in 1964, Trans-Pacific Cable 1 was the first coaxial cable to link Japan and the U.S. via landing sites in Guam and Hawaii. It was also part of a global communications network that linked tracking stations, command centers, and other infrastructure during the Apollo missions, including the moon landing in 1969. TPC-1 carried voice signals across the ocean for twenty-six years and, since 1990, the decommissioned cable has been used to study earthquakes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When they set up their cable station in Cromer, Australia, the PIPE International team decided to take a new approach to dealing with the surrounding public. Instead of hiding the network’s development, they started a blog where they posted photos of the cable’s installation, the equipment they used, and the operators’ activities. One engineer recounts that they tried to do community outreach as well. At one point they hosted a barbeque and asked residents to come see why the company had occupied their park for several months. As he described: “a lot of PR went into it to make sure the objections and problems were minimized.” Instead, they made the cable laying “a social event.” PIPE’s efforts have paid off. Not only did their outreach efforts generate publicity for their network, but they have had few problems with the local community since they began operation.

The Piti cable station, built just down the road from Naval Base Guam, is a fiber-optic superstation. Financed during the cable boom and was built in 2002 to land the Tyco Transpacific Network, the building is enormous, though when you enter, the reception desk remains empty, occupied only by a small security camera. You move through a large, hollow room containing rows of empty cubicles, into expansive halls of equipment, and down a cavernous hallway. On one side of the hallway is a giant battery plant in which everything is red; this is the red plant. Round plate batteries are stacked in many rows. On the other side of the hallway is a mirror version of the same plant, but blue; this is the blue plant. The station stands in contrast to the clustered, layered, and remade spaces of the Cold War buildings, Tumon and Tanguisson, further north on the island. There are no photos on the wall, or anything to mark that you are on Guam. The station has been meticulously designed, completely redundant, and with more than enough power and space to land several other systems. The station, like many others, has been overbuilt in anticipation of future growth; afterward, the market crashed and no networks landed here until 2009. There is plenty of extra room to offer to other cable networks, data or call centers, and services for digital content generation.

The PPC-1 cable, laid in 2009 to connect Australia, Guam, and Papua New Guinea, has enough capacity to carry simultaneous phone calls from the entire population of Australia – over twenty million people. Countries don't need to have an extensive network in part due to the enormous capacity of fiber optics.

Tschifu is today called Yantai, meaning “smoky tower.” In a way, this harbor town was always a critical communications node: the name refers back to the Ming Dynasty, when locals would light smoky fires to warn the village of approaching Japanese pirates. On the north-eastern tip of the Shandong Peninsula, Tschifu was directly south of Dairen, due west of Seoul, and straight north from Shanghai. Its central location made it an ideal cable hub during the telegraph era. In the first decade of the twentieth century, ten cables were landed here, connecting to Tsingtau, Port Arthur, Taku, Dairen, Shanghai, and Wei-hai-wei. Even before the cables were landed, the city had long been an important traffic hub: it had been an international trading port for almost half a century and seventeen nations had established embassies there.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When China began to struggle against imperialism in the late 1800s, Qingdao was an important node of resistance. The Boxers, an anti-imperialist, proto-nationalist Chinese movement, had a strong presence in area, and in 1897, the Chinese government began building up a military base here to protect against foreign invasion. Shortly thereafter, German troops seized and occupied this fort. After a year of fighting, China conceded the area to Germany, who re-named the city Tsingtau, a French transliteration of the original name. This small Chinese fishing village was transformed into a German administrative and economic center, with tall three-story stone buildings, wide streets, electricity, and a navy base. At the turn of the century, two telegraph cables were landed, one connecting to Tschifu and one to Shanghai. Today, two major cable systems continue to land at Qingdao, linking the city to Korea and across the sea to California.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 19th century, the first undersea network extended around the globe. The British pioneered this effort, drawing upon their technical expertise and naval resources. Many of these early systems followed colonial transportation and trade routes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1903, Telcon, I have no evidence except 1900s?_Asia Cable Map_MG_4065 but I think this extends on to Menado

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1903, the Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company received a contract from the Dutch East Indies Government to lay a cable between Balikpapan and Menado with a stop in Kwandang. Covering roughly 650 miles, the cable was deployed by sister ships Restorer and Patrol, launched from England that year and sold for scrap to the Japanese only a decade later.

An oil boom in the early 1900s transformed Balikpapan from a small fishing village into a center of petroleum production. It became the regional headquarters of the Bataafsche Petroleum Company in 1907, and tankers carrying petrol and paraffin wax soon filled the harbor. Balikpapan’s industrial success spurred investment in roads, buildings, and communications: this included three undersea cables set up by the Dutch East Indies Government and a high-powered wireless telegraph station that could transmit signals hundreds of miles to other colonial settlements. Cable and wireless telegraphy proved invaluable for coordinating petroleum shipping in the area. Oil merchants, explains a 1914 article, “call first at Balikpapan or at some other port in telegraphic communication with Balikpapan so that the latter is always advised by telegraph of the prospective sailings and calls and requirements of these tank boats.”

A 1903 guidebook describes the bay of Kwandang as “beautiful and picturesque” but also “abandoned” and “densely covered with vegetation.” There is “scarcely a house or sign of cultivation . . . to be seen anywhere in the midst of the primeval wood.” The town is located inland from the port and is largely invisible through the foliage. Although secluded, “the neatness of the roads and houses proves that Kwandang is not a self-governed country, but under Dutch Government.” The Portuguese arrived in the 1500s and built a stone fort to defend the region from pirates. A century later, the Dutch took possession of the island-filled bay, one of the best natural harbors in northern Sulawesi. In 1903, they linked it by submarine cable to Balikpapan and Menado. Despite clear signs of development, however, Kwandang remained a wild place. A gang of pirates besieged the colony in the late 1800s until Dutch ships finally “came to the rescue from Ternate.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Menado derives from the word manadou or wanazou, meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island North Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town has grown into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor make it difficult to anchor. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations have developed. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.
This cable extends Tata Communications’ global network into Southeast Asia, connecting major hubs in Singapore and Hong Kong with smaller stations in Vietnam and the Philippines.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Tata Communications

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1990-2003 (AtlanticCable.com says landed at Cape D' Aguilar; Subsea Book says Deep Water Bay)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For decades, Taiwan’s cables had been concentrated at its northern and southern tips. While the Tanshui and Toucheng stations are on the fringes of Taipei, the Chunghwa Telecom station is located in the rural southern township of Fangshan. Most traffic to Southeast Asia, whether from Taiwan, East Asia, or North America, passes through the Bashi Strait, the narrow passage separating Taiwan and the Philippines. Fangshan was the ideal gateway to this route until recently, when a spate of natural disasters severed numerous cable links. An earthquake in September 1999 broke Taiwan’s terrestrial backbone, one undersea cable, and caused cell sites and radio relays to collapse. The 2006 Hengchun earthquake caused submarine landslides that took out nine undersea links. Most recently,  Typhoon Morakot disrupted six international cables and 1700 wireless base stations, in addition to taking 500 lives. Fangshan, perched on the edge of the Bashi Strait, is no longer a popular interconnection point for undersea traffic.

Fiber optic systems, which encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass, have been in development since the early 1980s. Given the conservatism of the industry, the first international system was not put in place until 1986. The immense capacity of these systems have made possible the internet as we know it today.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center). Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

In 2012, a consortium of telecom companies led by China Unicom signed a construction and maintenance agreement for the Asia-Pacific Gateway (APG) cable system, due to open in 2015. The system is specially routed to avoid areas prone to seismic activity while providing additional capacity along the region’s existing international networks.

This final link extended the Commercial Pacific Cable Company's network from Manila to Shanghai in 1906. On July 4th, United States President Theodore Roosevelt and the president of the Commercial Pacific Cable Company, Clarence Mackay, exchanged messages that telegraphically encircled the globe.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Pratt and Roosevelt. “Developments in the Field of Cable and Radio Telegraph Communications." AIEE Technical Paper (May 1944), 3.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Although it started out as a small farm town, Shanghai grew into an important and busy port during the Qing Dynasty. In 1842, after the British defeated the Chinese in the first Opium War, Shanghai became a treaty port, occupied by British forces and open for international trade. Throughout the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries, the city grew rapidly. Tall municipal buildings and three-story stone houses with red roofs lined the wide and busy streets. The ports were congested with naval and trade ships from Britain, France, and Japan. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, connecting the city to Singapore and Hong Kong. As the cable was laid up the Yangtze River to Shanghai, men armed with rifles patrolled it to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the connection. By 1916, ten more cables - sponsored by a range of governments and militaries - had landed here, linking to Japan, Russia, Yap, the Philippines, and other Chinese ports.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 4, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1942, Japan diverted a German cable (originally laid in 1905 between Menado, Yap, and Guam) to Palau, where it had military installations and regional government headquarters from 1914 to 1944.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. Yap formed an important bridge between America and China. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s traffic out of the country.

The town of Koror in the Palau archipelago was once known as “Little Tokyo,” a nod to the strong Japanese presence on the islands between the First and Second World Wars. Palau’s strategic position in the North Pacific drew competing territorial claims from Britain, Spain, and Germany in the late 1800s. After a period of Spanish rule, the fertile islands were sold to the Germans who began exploiting their natural resources. Japan annexed Palau in 1914, established a regional government headquarters, promoted large-scale immigration, and built fish canneries and coconut processing plants. During World War II, a German telegraph cable was redirected to Palau to strengthen communication links to Japan. And in 1944, Japanese and U.S. forces clashed in the months-long Battle of Peleliu (an island in southeastern Palau) with heavy casualties on both sides.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Gordon L. Rottman, World War II Pacific Island Guide: A Geo-Military Study. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was reportedly critical for scanning communications about events including the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Spectacular surface formations are cut into the sedimentary rock, some locals observe that these even resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of the coast. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

When it was finished in December 2005, the consortium-owned Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 4 cable provided both additional bandwidth and greater redundancy along the bulk of the previous-generation SeaMeWe-3 line between the Mediterranean and Singapore. SeaMeWe-3, however, extends significantly further to points in China, Japan, Australia, the U.K., and Germany, among others.

One of the first fiber cable systems laid in the Pacific, Hawaii-4 was also one of the shortest lived. It went out of service after a mere 15 years, not because it broke, but rather due to economic obsolescence.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

To get to California’s oldest still operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco on narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

AT&T has been integral to the laying of submarine cables since the 1950s. During the Cold War period, cable laying was "club" affair - only nationally-affiliated telecommunications companies could participate. AT&T facilitated all of the United States' transoceanic projects during this time, and built an number of cable stations on US shores.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1901-1966; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Co; Anglia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This line, a diverse circuit to Australia, was strung across the Indian Ocean in 1901. It operated until 1966.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, worked, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, these low-lying islands still hold tropical forests, surrounded by soft beaches. There are no hills or mountains on the Cocos, and pools of fresh water collect here and there in the soil when it rains. True to their name, the islands’ sole export is coconuts, which hang heavily from palm trees everywhere you look.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Located in the Indian Ocean, close to Africa, this 108 square kilometer piece of earth was formed by volcanic eruptions 1.5 million years ago, making it very small, and geologically, very young. The island was uninhabited by humans for most of its short history, yet bustled with unique plant and animal life, unaffected by intervention or cultivation. Throughout the 17th and 18th century both the Dutch and the French tried to settle and farm the island, their efforts stymied by loneliness more than by the land itself. The French, who had brought African slaves from Mauritius, eventually gave up on farming and exhausted the island’s large tortoise population by using it to supply meat to passing ships. When the British took possession of the island in 1809, slavery was abolished and the freed slaves and colonists built a small but somewhat stable economy through tobacco and food exports. With commerce comes communication, and in 1901 the British landed a telegraph cable here, stopping between Mauritius and the Cocos Islands, and making this tiny place an essential node.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Undiscovered until the 1500s, no humans had ever lived on this tiny, untouched tropical island off the east coast of Madagascar. But by the early 1900s, Mauritius was one of the most connected places on the planet. The British took control of this island after the Napoleonic Wars and began farming sugar cane here, using indentured laborers from India. The cable came shortly thereafter, making Mauritius a stopping point between South Africa and Asia. The workers who came here, whether to raise cane or transmit signals, might have felt like they landed in Eden: the land is lush and bright green, with steep mountains rising above rolling fields. The world’s third largest coral reef surrounds the island, protecting the lagoons, where the water is so clear and clean that you can see right through it. Today, the island is still remote and protected, yet connected. Two major fiber-optic networks run cables to either end of the landmass,  which recently was ranked as having some of the freshest air in the world. Strange animals survive everywhere: brightly colored Geckos crawl along branches, monkeys swing from the trees, and wild pigs rustle in the underbrush.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades starting in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

The South Africa-Far East (SAFE) cable system, built in 2002 by a U.S. company, traverses the Indian Ocean on a path similar to the one taken by Portuguese explorers in the fifteenth century. By joining the SAT-3/WASC cable at Melkbosstrand, South Africa, SAFE provides a direct optical fiber link between Western Europe and Malaysia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Kyushu Electric Power,  KT,  Softbank Telecom,  NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Kitakyushu has been a networked industrial center in southern Japan for more than a century. Beginning in the early 1900s, Japan’s largest steel mill refined iron ore from Korea and China into metal for shipbuilding and the rapidly expanding railroad system. This made Kitakyushu a target during the Second World War, including the original target for the bomb later dropped on Nagasaki. Today, the city is home to Kyushu’s largest ferry port and second-largest train station, as well as a factory that produces more than three thousand miles of submarine cable each year. It’s also the birthplace of celebrated Japanese crime novelist Seichō Matsumoto. In his 1957 bestseller Points and Lines, police investigators discover two bodies on a secluded beach and use railway schedules to locate the suspects in time and space.

Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “Kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

Busan is a major gateway for East Asian cable traffic, with five submarine networks interconnecting at this station. It is also where some of the best seaweed in South Korea is grown, one cableman tells you. Unfortunately, the boom in South Korean seaweed production, which comprises over half of the country’s aquaculture, doesn’t benefit international signal traffic. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s shore twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting them, fishermen come close to the country’s international communications lines. When building a new system, cable companies aren’t allowed to dig into the seabed, since this might disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Instead they carefully place each cable in a “mattress” before lowering it down into the crop.

A partnership between Korea Telecom, Japan Telecom, NTT Communications, and the Kyushu Electric Power Company, this cable entered service ahead of the 2002 World Cup, co-hosted by the two countries. From Busan, the system makes two, 150-mile journeys across the Korea Strait to Kyushu, a trade route that dates back to the 14th century.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. Seeing that this was precarious, English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

Ken Beauchamp, History of Telegraphy (IEE History of Technology Series). London: The Institution of Engineering and Technology, 2001. 135-8.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, laid under the direction of Danish engineer Emanuel Hansen, completed the first electric link between Taiwan and China. In China, it was landed at the mouth of the Min River, in Fuzhou.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though the islands are sparsely populated, they have long been connected by communications networks. In 1887, the government landed a cable here, connecting to China on one side and to the rest of Taiwan on the other. Less than ten years later, the Chinese attacked and attempted to take possession of the islands, but were driven away by the Japanese, who were then occupying Penghu and later, all of Taiwan. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked China and Taiwan. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Remains of stone-age cultures have been found in Fuzhou, dating back to 5000 B.C.E. Over the millennia, many civilizations have arisen and fallen on this land. In the 10th century, tall pagodas were erected to protect the city from “evil influences of atmospheric currents.” Such currents brought human trouble more than atmospheric calamity, as the site became desirable to foreign imperial powers. The waterways that run along the city make it ideal for trading and transportation, while the rich, wet earth cultivates rice fields, and the nearby island-protected harbors provide good anchor for military and trade ships. By the 19th century, Fuzhou had grown into a large walled city with a population of over half a million. Westerners ran major trade operations from the city following the British victory in the first Opium War, which opened the port – then called Foochow – to foreign trade. More recently, the area has been opened to foreign circulations in another way: Fuzhou has been declared a free trade zone, and a new fiber-optic cable lands there linking to Taiwan. As goods and signals flow in and out freely, the economy has become less stable. Fuzhou is now known for supplying America with a labor force, as young adults from its suburbs come to the United States to work long hours at low wages.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Ben Ross, “Coming to America…Fuzhou’s Main Export is People,” Urban Sociology and Urbanism, in China and North America, accessed September 12, 2013, http://benross.net/wordpress/illegal-immigration/2007/05/22/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 9, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Rev. Stephen Livingstone Baldwin, “A Trip to China,” Frank Leslie’s Popular Monthly xviii (July-December, 1884), accessed September 9, 2013, http://www.gnudoyng.net/christianity/1884_foo-chow.php.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it opened in 1991, the North Pacific Cable was the highest-capacity system to link Japan and North America. “This pioneering effort helps usher in what futurists . . . call the fibersphere,” declared the president of Pacific Telecom, the cable’s U.S. sponsor. The following year, Tokyo Broadcasting System sent high-definition television signals between Miura and Pacific City to demonstrate the “Advantages of terrestrial fiber transmission” over satellite, including “high bandwidth, high reliability and less delay.”

Forming the southern edge of Tokyo Bay, the Miura Peninsula received its first domestic underwater cables in the 1970s. In the 1990s, international systems joined Miura to the rest of Asia, Europe, and the U.S., echoing a long history of maritime connections. In 1600, English navigator William Adams arrived in Japan and became a government advisor on shipbuilding and foreign affairs. Renamed “the pilot of Miura,” Adams settled near present-day Yokosuka in eastern Miura, now a major Japanese and U.S. naval base. More than four hundred years later, Minoru Saito became the oldest person to sail non-stop around the world at age 71, beginning and ending in Miura. The 234-day solo journey was his seventh circumnavigation.

In 1991, North Pacific Cable built a brand new station on the remote Oregon coast. Established far from the AT&T landing in Bandon, this building pioneered cable landing in northern Oregon, now a critical stopping point for Internet entering and leaving the country. Even though it paved the way for development, North Pacific Cable was eventually made obsolete by these newer links, and with this, the station was shut down. It was not until years afterward that Tillamook Lightwave purchased the station in order to help provide regional access to the network. Part of the station was leased to the University of Washington for their "Regional Scale Nodes" project, an ocean cable system that enables scientists to observe deep sea life forms and processes. A building constructed merely to funnel signals through the area now links the many populations, human and non-human, on the Oregon coast.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Appropriately named Keoje, Korean for “great crossing,” this island is the landing site of several international submarine cable networks, though it is still smaller than the hub in nearby Pusan. As you come ashore through clear waters, the sound you hear is not heavy rainfall but the pebbles on Hakdong beach tumbling in the surf. Named after a crane (“hak” in Korean), this wing-shaped beach sits in a valley covered by flowering camellia plants, sheltered from the industrial shipyards and granite mines further north. Eschewing the discrete architecture of many contemporary cable facilities, the Korea Telecom landing station calls attention to itself with an ornate design. Decorative columns and topiaries line the station’s brick and glass entryway, which faces away from Hakdong’s beachfront promenade.

Entering service in 1997, the FLAG (Fiber-Optic Link Around the Globe) Europe-Asia cable system connects the United Kingdom with Japan via more than a dozen landing sites. The cable, now operated by an Indian telecom, was the subject of a 1996 Wired magazine article by cyberpunk author Neal Stephenson in which he traveled to “six countries and four continents trying to get a grip on this longest, fastest, mother of all wires.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. Unlike many modern stations, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Although it was originally a swampy wetland, Ancol is now something like the Disneyworld of Indonesia, bustling with rides, beach-goers, and children. Perched on the northern edge of East Java, in Jakarta Bay, it lies in between the upscale waterfront neighborhood of Pantai Mutiara and a busy international ferry terminal. The spot draws visitors from Jakarta and nearby Javanese cities, as well as many who cross the Java and South China Seas, coming to vacation from Sumatra, Singapore, or the Philippines. Cables have trafficked signals into the area since 1859, when an undersea cable connected from a neighborhood just south of Ancol to Singapore and the rest of Asia.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Weltevreden, Batavia is today’s Sawah Besar, a section of Jakarta, Indonesia. The area was built up and named by the Dutch East India Company in the 17th and 18th centuries. In the 19th Century it became a full-fledged Dutch colony and in 1859 a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Hong Kong. Had you arrived at that time, you would have found an established colonial city with a busy port. The area closer to the water held warehouses and offices of many trading companies. Weltevreden was more stately, with shops and government offices. Writings from that period describe the cable station as “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it had a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. Today the area still bears traces of the earlier colonial period. The central square, laid out by the Dutch in the 19th century, displays symmetrical paths and gardens lined with palm trees, which lead to a statue celebrating Indonesia’s independence. In the same neighborhood, a large cathedral sits nearby a temple that is home to both Buddhist and Hindu practitioners, built in Dutch Colonial style.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world.

In Malay and Indonesian mythology, the pontianak is a vampiric ghost, the spirit of a woman who dies while pregnant. The town of Pontianak is named after one such woman, said to have haunted the first Sultan who ruled the area. Founded in 1771 on swampy ground near an old coastal trading station, Pontianak is watery, foggy, and not entirely terrestrial. The early settlement became a center of piratical activity as well as a port for the Dutch East Indies Company. In the 19th century the land officially became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies. As the port grew in size it was built mostly on stilts due to the swampy land. At the turn of the 20th century, it was the French, however, not the Dutch, who laid an undersea cable to the site, connecting to French Indochina. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

The portion of the network owned by TM is branded Cahaya Malaysia (“cahaya” is the Indonesian word for “light”).

Previously, signal traffic was routed through other hubs in regional networks. To some, the cable represents a major step toward greater economic cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A 12th-century sea wall lines the edge of a small village where cables land. Locals come here to take in the panorama, looking east across the ocean. The clear seawater carries you up to white, rocky beaches, abutted by deep green brush leading into steep hills and low forests. The history of this village stretches back hundreds of years, when the sea wall and castle were built, forming the administrative and cultural center of the area. Yet the remoteness of the village made it appealing to cable companies during the coaxial period. After the destruction of World War II, companies surfaced cables far away from urban centers, like Okinawa City, which might be potential targets. In the 1970s and 1980s, a number of important international cables were landed here in Gushikami, making this rural land a submarine communications hub. More recently, the abandoned TPC-2 cable to Guam was revived for geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in 2000, the consortium-owned China-U.S. Cable Network was the first direct cable route between the two countries. It consists of dual Pacific crossings, forming a ring structure with connections along the west coast of the U.S. and between several Southeast Asian hubs. Only a year after it entered service, however, the anchor of a fishing boat off Chongming Island disrupted much of the traffic between China and the U.S..

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Tonga Communications Corporation,  Government of Tonga

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Walking around this cable landing, you take care not to fall in the ditches carved into the landscape. Trash clutters the cable landing area, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of a major city, Suva. Yet unlike many cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the station. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing. Visiting, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers -- this is a place for meeting. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

This cable, which links Tonga to Fiji and the entire Southern Cross trans-Pacific network, was completed in August 2013 with major funding from the Asian Development Bank and World Bank. Run by the government-owned Tonga Cable Limited, it is part of a larger effort to connect smaller island nations in the Pacific.

In 1902, as part of a wave of strategically and nationally driven cables in the early twentieth century, the French post and telegraph service laid a system between Tourane, in French Indochina, to Amoy, China.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You find yourself stuck in a building on the water, in an assemblage of similar, elegant structures. The post office, hotels, and assorted administrative buildings all are built in French colonial style, often painted yellow with white trim. Many possess balconies, large arched windows, and manicured gardens. Outside, the port of Tourane is busy with trading ships, which linger in the harbor, where the Hàn River opens into the South China Sea. Steep mountains rich in coal surround the town and farther inland, the river is lined by rice fields. With such resources have come colonial empires, and with empires, have come cables.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “The view of the harbor in clear weather is beautiful and animated,” notes an 1897 travel guide to Surabaya. Under Dutch rule since 1743, it was the main commercial port and largest Dutch naval base in the East Indies. “On the water and along the quays great bustle prevails. . . . Chinese and Javanese, Europeans and Arabs, citizens and soldiers mingle” in the crowded streets. The arrival of two Dutch submarine cables in 1913 and 1921 brought the city into further contact with other settlements in the region. But Surabaya’s growth and vibrancy was interrupted by conflict in the 1940s. The city was captured by the Japanese and bombed by Allied forces in the Second World War. And in the 1945 Battle of Surabaya, Indonesian soldiers fought British troops for national independence. This history of profound struggle resonates with the name Surabaya, which some say derives from a mythical battle between two powerful creatures, a “sura” (shark) and a “baya” (crocodile).

Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch forces vied with local rulers for control of this small volcanic island, the northern gateway to the “spice islands” of Maluku and once the world’s only source of cloves. In the 1600s, the Dutch seized Ternate and began to manage trade in the region. The East India Company created a monopoly on cloves by destroying all non-Dutch plantations and making unauthorized growing punishable by death. Trade expansion necessitated faster communication channels, and in 1913 an underwater cable connected Ternate to Dutch settlements in Java and Borneo. As clove production spread elsewhere, the island became less centrally important. But a nearly 400-year-old clove tree—the oldest in the world—still stands on Ternate as evidence of its past distinctiveness.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Asia-America Gateway (AAG), opened in 2009, was the first high-bandwidth optical cable to provide a direct link between Southeast Asia and California (via the Philippines, Guam, and Hawaii). Positioned further south than other trans-Pacific routes, AAG avoids the seismically active areas near Taiwan where earthquakes are known to cause cable disruptions.

Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

In the late 1980s Trans-Pacific Cable 3, a joint venture by AT&T, Japan’s KDD, and several other companies, was one of the first optical cables to cross the Pacific. With TPC-3, “fiber-optic technology now links Europe, North America, and Asia,” proclaimed the New York Times in April 1989. This offered several advantages: it was a second or two faster than satellite transmissions, as well as more secure, cheaper to operate, and less prone to interference than copper lines.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To build GOKI, AT&T commissioned two Japanese cable companies to pull up 800 miles of retired underwater networks, including portions of TPC-5. These fragments were then reengineered and combined with new fibers to create a much faster optical link between Japan and Guam.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Interchange

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On a rainy November morning in 2013, a French cable team collaborated with a local construction crew to complete Vanuatu’s first underwater fiber-optic connection: a link to Fiji and the Southern Cross network. After surfacing on the black sand beaches of Mele Bay outside Port Vila, the cable runs inland to a modular station, assembled from five prefabricated units roughly the size of shipping containers. A high cinderblock wall surrounds the entire facility, blocking out potential intruders and making it less prominent than nearby medicinal gardens, coffee-roasting plants, and microbreweries. Through physically discrete, the station’s economic and cultural impact was by no means overlooked. Earlier that year, thousands gathered along the Port Vila waterfront to celebrate National Information and Communication Technologies Day and the cable’s impending arrival.
Owned by the Vanuatu-based telecom company Interchange and installed by France’s Alcatel-Lucent, this cable stretches over 700 miles between Port Vila and Suva, Fiji.

Dairen, Manchuria is today’s Dalian, China. This port city sits on a peninsula that juts out into the Yellow Sea, bisecting the Chinese mainland and North Korea, and threading together the region’s histories of communications and transport. At the time of its first cable landing, this piece of land was under Russian control. Valued in part because of its southern location, the port gave the Russians year-round access to the Pacific. During their occupation, the Russians gradually transformed Dairen from a small fishing village to a busy naval and shipping harbor, where small wooden warehouses, cranes, and a railroad lined the water. When the Russo-Japanese War broke out in 1904, the Japanese quickly took control of the port and brought in a telegraph cable. In 1908, a new cable linked the city to China, but accepted messages only in Japanese outside certain portions of the day. Eventually the city was transferred back to the Russians, and finally to the Chinese government in 1950.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French company, La Societe Française des Télégraphes Sous-Marins, extended this cable from the Australian coast to New Caledonia in 1893, as part of a project to link France to its colonies.

On the shore at Mon Repos, a group of sea turtle hatchlings makes their way across the sandy beach and into the ocean. Long before this beach became a conservation park for the now endangered turtles, the site was a landing for a French telegraph cable. It was a short-lived system, connecting the nearby municipality of Bundaberg with the French colony of New Caledonia. At that time, Bundaberg and its environs were hardly developed. The area was populated by a small group of European timbergetters and farmers, and an established indigenous population of Kabi people, from whose language the city derives its name. A sawmill was built along the municipality’s river in 1868, drawing surveyors and settlers, and a sugar mill was built in 1882, around which a successful industry grew. This small, industrial, mostly British town had little interest in New Caledonia, a French colony known mostly for its political prisoners and fledgling mining industry.

In 1893, New Caledonia is changing. The prisoners have almost all left, and commerce is coming. A telegraph cable is being landed on New Caledonia’s soft shores. Inland, low brush and flowering bushes lead to dry meadows dotted with trees, providing little obstacle to the cable. Farther in, green and brown peaks soar upwards. Almost three decades earlier, nickel was discovered in these mountains, and since then the French have been mining the island. Despite their efforts at immigration, New Caledonia is now largely unpopulated by Europeans. Not long ago, the island was a French penal colony, where over 20,000 criminals and political prisoners were held. Many of them were Communards, punished for creating a self-governing socialist society in Paris. The cells emptied out when they were granted amnesty in 1879. With the discovery of nickel, the place began to serve a new purpose, and the French government hoped to establish itself in the South Pacific by making New Caledonia a hub.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid 16th century. Portuguese shacks gradually grew into a settlement, but much of the area remained governed by and inhabited by the Chinese. It was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation to Portugal in exchange for a promise that Portugal would help Hong Kong with trade and import taxes. Shortly thereafter, in 1884, a telegraph cable connected the two cities. The city remained a Portuguese colony until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via modern cable technology, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Hong Kong was one of the telegraph hubs of the British Empire and a key entry point into China. The first undersea link connected the island in 1871, and in the years that followed, cables extended outward from the island to Shanghai, Manila, and other locations in the Pacific. From their landing at Telegraph Bay, named for the cables, they connected inland to the busy Eastern Extension office. Today the landing site is the location of the Cyberport, a "creative digital community" built to foster information technology development in light of the expanding internet.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Batam cable station looks out across rusty brown sand and a dark blue sea. Somewhere across that water is Singapore, where the other end of the cable has landed since 2006. The station shares the shore with many other industries – nearby you glimpse silhouettes of cranes and oil rigs. Not much farther along the coast there are ship-repair yards and a number of ferry ports. Fiber-optic signals run underneath, and support, the transfer of goods and people to and from Singapore on the water's surface. Part of a free trade zone, the whole area is a bit lassiez-faire. Batam does not exert a large amount of control over the information, commerce, or people that stream in and out. The city itself serves the appetites of the workers and businessmen who have come to build up these industries, offering restaurants, bars, and an infamous nightlife. Even the taxis and the driving speeds remain unregulated.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the turn of the twenty-first century, three cables came ashore on the rural coast of western Oregon. While systems of the coaxial period usually terminated close to shore, these lines wind inland for over seventy miles, through the fir-populated mountains of the Tillamook State Forest to a Portland suburb nestled in the heart of “Silicon Forest.” The area was first granted this nickname in 1981, only a few years after Intel established a research campus there. Yet the seeds of Silicon Forest were planted much earlier. In the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service Radio Lab was created in Portland, and developed wireless technologies to track fires as they spread through the forest, including the one that now borders the cable route. Engineers at the Radio Lab eventually developed two of Portland’s most well-known technology companies, setting the stage for today’s high-tech boom. Hillsboro, Oregon is now the home to many computer researchers, chip manufacturers, and cable stations, as well as a budding hub of data center activity. Companies are drawn to Silicon Forest because of its “welcoming” environment: not only do companies get massive tax breaks they in Hillsboro’s E-Commerce zone, but they have immediate access to cheap hydroelectric power from the nearby Columbia River.

Constructed in 2008 by a consortium of six telecom companies, the Trans-Pacific Express (TPE) cable is a major link between sites in the South China Sea (China, South Korea, and Taiwan) and the west coast of the United States. An extension to Japan opened in 2010. It greatly increased connection speeds across the Pacific, bringing them up to those found in trans-Atlantic cables.
